definition: lit. the voice of the guest overwhelms that of the host (idiom)/fig. a minor player upstages the main attraction/minor details obscure the main point/the sauce is better than the fish
clamor/noise
variant of 喧[xuan1]/old variant of 諼|谖[xuan1]
visitor/guest/object (in grammar)
to seize/to take away forcibly/to wrest control of/to compete or strive for/to force one's way through/to leave out/to lose
owner/master/host/individual or party concerned/God/Lord/main/to indicate or signify/trump card (in card games)

sentences.english: Design of adornment of some setting wall is too messy, often a presumptuous guest usurps the host's role.
sentences.chinese: 有些背景墙装饰设计过于散乱，往往喧宾夺主。

sentences.english: One problem with selfies is that most have distracting backgrounds.
sentences.chinese: 很多人自拍的问题在于背景喧宾夺主。

sentences.english: Too luxuriant decoration usually supersedes what really counts.
sentences.chinese: 过于华丽的装饰往往会喧宾夺主。

definition: to steal the show/to grab the limelight
lit. draw legs on a snake (idiom); fig. to ruin the effect by adding sth superfluous/to overdo it
to enhance by contrast/to set off/to serve as a background in order to bring out the subject with greater brilliance/to serve as a prop/a foil
to paint a dragon and dot in the eyes (idiom); fig. to add the vital finishing touch/the crucial point that brings the subject to life/a few words to clinch the point
it's just perfect/it's just right
lofty or towering/sudden or abrupt
out of place/inappropriate/incongruous
to overreach oneself/to try to be clever and end up with egg on one's face
the brush stroke that dots in the eyes (idiom); fig. to add the vital finishing touch/the crucial point that brings the subject to life/a few words to clinch the point
lit. to go beyond the sacrificial altar and take over the kitchen (idiom); fig. to exceed one's place and meddle in other people's affairs/to take matters into one's own hands
tacky/inelegant/in poor taste/vulgar/banal
background (of a painting)/backdrop/a foil (to set off something to advantage)/to offset (something to advantage)
lit. to invert root and branch (idiom); fig. confusing cause and effect/to stress the incidental over the fundamental/to put the cart before the horse
excessive/undue/overly
garish/gaudy
to act cleverly to get what one desires/to get the best at least expense
